Mark Fisk with the Michigan Smart Trade Alliance says President Trump‚Äôs threats to block the new Gordie Howe International Bridge between Detroit and Windsor add to the instability in trade discussions. ‚ÄúThe on-again, off-again makes it almost impossible to plan,‚Äù […] The post Michigan alliance pushes ‚Äòsmart trade‚Äô as Trump targets Canada, Gordie Howe Bridge appeared first on Brownfield
items.summary: The Michigan Smart Trade Alliance is highlighting the negative impact of trade inconsistencies on farmers. President Trump's threats to block the new Gordie Howe International Bridge between Detroit and Windsor, Ontario add to the instability in trade discussions, according to Mark Fisk of the alliance. The "on-again, off-again" nature of trade policy makes it "almost impossible to plan" for farmers. The alliance is advocating for "smart trade" policies that provide stability and predictability for the agricultural sector.

items.title: When Ohio loved snow: The history of pioneer sleighing traditions
items.description: Before snowplows, Ohioans relished the snow. Explore the history of pioneer sleighing with history columnist Paul Locher, from foot warmers to sleigh bells and community caravans. The post When Ohio loved snow: The history of pioneer sleighing traditions appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Towns owned snow rollers to compact snow on roads, facilitating sleighing and movement of agricultural equipment with runners. Sleighs ranged from simple work sleighs to fancy Albany and Portland cutters with decorative brass fittings and paint.

Sleighing required accessories like buggy robes (often made from animal hides), heavy gloves, and foot warmers (tin boxes with hot coals or stoneware with hot water). Snow knockers - blacksmith-made iron hammers - were used to remove ice and snow from horses' hooves. Sleigh bells alerted others to an approaching sleigh.

Sleighing also involved nighttime torchlight caravans to neighboring towns for parties around a bonfire, allowing residents to socialize and build community. This winter sleighing culture contrasts sharply with modern Ohioans' disdain for snow and investment in snow-fighting equipment.

items.title: Ag groups point to analysis in call for renewal of agreement
items.description: A new analysis says USMCA-driven trade with Canada and Mexico is a major economic engine for U.S. agriculture and rural jobs as leaders push for renewal. The post Ag groups point to analysis in call for renewal of agreement appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Agricultural leaders are highlighting new data showing the critical importance of the trade pact for rural America. 

According to an economic analysis by the Agricultural Coalition for USMCA:
- Agricultural and seafood exports to Canada and Mexico generated $149 billion in total economic output
- This supported nearly 500,000 American jobs and $36 billion in wages
- Since replacing NAFTA in 2020, USMCA has governed nearly $1.9 trillion in annual goods and services trade across North America
- Canada and Mexico account for over $60 billion in U.S. farm exports, nearly one-third of all American agricultural exports
- Every $1 in agricultural exports under USMCA generates an additional $2.45 in economic activity in the U.S.
- USMCA-related agricultural trade contributes $64 billion to U.S. GDP and supports $13 billion in tax revenue

Commodity groups highlighted specific gains, with fresh produce exports surging 34% for fruit and 14% for vegetables. Mexico is also a top export market for U.S. dairy.

The Agricultural Coalition for USMCA is urging policymakers to renew the agreement while making targeted improvements. They argue stability is crucial as farmers face high costs, volatile markets, and global competition. Maintaining efficient cross-border trade with Canada and Mexico is critical, supporting 13 million American jobs and 31% of U.S. trade-related rail traffic.

items.title: Soybean prices shook off dismal export data
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Corn prices were also firm on Thursday.
items.summary:
Soybean prices held steady on Thursday despite weaker-than-expected U.S. soybean export data. According to the USDA, U.S. soybean exports for the week ending Nov. 17 reached 1.18 million metric tons, down 26% from the previous week and below trade expectations.

However, soybeans for January delivery closed 7 cents higher at $15.02 per bushel. Corn for December delivery added 7 cents to $6.72 per bushel. Wheat for December delivery rose 10 cents to $8.08 per bushel.

The markets were focused on ongoing tight global supplies of grains and oilseeds, which continue to support prices. USDA data showed soybean ending stocks in 2022/23 are projected at just 222 million bushels, down 47% from 2021/22. Corn ending stocks are forecast at 1.182 billion bushels, down 7% year-over-year.

The lower-than-expected soybean exports could signal weaker demand, but traders seem more concerned about tight inventory levels globally. Analysts note that the market is still working to ration the tight soybean supplies.

items.title: CHS completes Galveston upgrade
items.description: Port modernization will triple railcar loading speed and improve on-time fertilizer delivery to farmers in the cooperative.
items.summary:
CHS has completed a $32 million upgrade to its fertilizer terminal in Galveston, Texas. The upgrade will triple the terminal's railcar loading speed from 40 to 120 cars per day. This will allow CHS to deliver fertilizer to farmers in its cooperative more quickly and reliably, improving on-time delivery from 89% to 95%.

The upgrades include additional storage, new rail infrastructure, and modernized loading equipment. CHS worked with the Port of Galveston on this project, which began in 2018 and was completed in 2022.

The improved efficiency will benefit CHS's farmer-owners by ensuring they receive crucial fertilizer supplies in time for planting seasons. Faster loading and delivery helps CHS meet peak spring and fall demand, when timely fertilizer application is essential for crop yields.

items.title: From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management
items.description: Learn how zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are driving efficiency, sustainability, and stronger returns across every acre. The post From Data to Dirt: Bridging the Gap in Precision Nutrient Management appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Zone-based feeding, advanced equipment, and intelligent systems are enabling more precise, data-driven nutrient application. This helps optimize fertilizer use and reduce environmental impact.

- A University of Illinois study found that variable-rate nitrogen application increased yields by 6-10% and reduced nitrogen use by 9-15% compared to uniform application.

- The Climate FieldView platform allows farmers to combine yield data, soil maps, and other information to create variable-rate nutrient prescriptions. This is used on over 130 million acres.

- Equipment like the John Deere R4060 Sprayer can adjust application rates on the go based on real-time data, improving efficiency.

- Precision Planting's FieldSmart system uses AI and sensors to automatically adjust seeding, fertilizer, and other inputs based on field conditions.

- Experts say precision nutrient management is crucial for sustainable farming, helping reduce costs, emissions, and environmental damage while boosting yields and profits.

items.title: First look: KIOTI expands compact tractor lineup with CK40SE
items.description: KIOTI has given several upgrades to its CK compact tractor lineup, debuting the CK40SE model at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show. The post First look: KIOTI expands compact tractor lineup with CK40SE appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The KIOTI CK40SE compact tractor was unveiled at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky. Some key updates include:

- Swapped out backlit analog gauges for a new 10.25-inch color LCD display, allowing integration with the KIOTI Connect system for alerts and information.
- Replaced the single right-hand brake pedal with two pedals on the left side, providing a differential brake.
- Upgraded the tilt steering to a telescopic steering wheel for more fluid positioning.
- Redesigned the fuel tank with a repositioned filler neck.
- New loaders have a quick-release pinless design and rerouted hose connections for improved visibility.
- Added a new four-point backhoe mount, while keeping the lower three-point hitch links accessible.
- Increased the size and comfort of the backhoe operator station, with a toolbox underneath.

The CK40SE is targeted at large-property owners, small farmers, and rural lifestyle/hobby farmers who need a maneuverable compact tractor for tasks like barn/building cleanup, light dirt work, and other small jobs. KIOTI product development manager Joel Hicks highlighted the tractor's versatility and improved operator experience.

items.title: USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô
items.description: February 12, 2026 ‚Äì Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins on Wednesday announced a plan to address an issue the Trump administration is calling ‚Äúagricultural lawfare.‚Äù Rollins made the announcement at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers, coinciding with the release of the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework. […] The post USDA Debuts Plan to End ‚ÄòAgricultural Lawfare‚Äô appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has announced a plan to address "agricultural lawfare", which refers to the use of lawsuits to disrupt agricultural operations. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins unveiled the Farmer and Rancher Freedom Framework on February 12, 2026, aiming to protect farmers and ranchers from frivolous lawsuits.

The key elements of the plan include:
- Creating a legal defense fund to help farmers and ranchers fight lawsuits
- Establishing an "agricultural ombudsman" office to mediate disputes before they reach the courts
- Implementing a "loser pays" rule, where plaintiffs who lose lawsuits will be responsible for the defendant's legal fees

The plan was announced at an event with officials from other federal agencies and a group of farmers and ranchers. It is intended to provide farmers and ranchers with the legal support and protection they need to continue their operations without fear of costly and disruptive lawsuits.

The goal is to reduce the burden of "agricultural lawfare" on the farming community and ensure that farmers and ranchers can focus on food production without unnecessary legal challenges. This initiative is expected to have a positive impact on the agricultural sector by reducing legal costs and providing greater certainty for farmers and ranchers.

items.title: Culver’s debuts new contest ahead of FFA week for local chapters
items.description: Culver‚Äôs is strengthening its support for the next generation of agricultural leaders with the launch of their brand-new True Blue Chapters Contest. The post Culver’s debuts new contest ahead of FFA week for local chapters appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The contest allows guests, FFA members, and advisors to nominate local FFA chapters they believe should be recognized. Five selected chapters will each have the opportunity to earn up to $2,500 by participating in Culver's "Thank You Farmers Project" events and activities throughout the year. 

The contest recognizes FFA chapters for their leadership, engagement, and community impact. Nominations open on February 16 and close on March 13. Culver's guests can also support local FFA chapters by donating $1 for a Blue Barn decal at participating restaurants from February 23-27.

In addition to the new contest, Culver's will continue its annual "Scoops of Thanks Day" fundraiser on May 7, 2026, where $1 from every scoop of Fresh Frozen Custard sold goes to local FFA chapters. In 2025, over $170,000 was raised through this initiative. Culver's also has a presence at the National FFA Convention each year.

Alison Demmer, Culver's senior public relations manager, stated that supporting FFA chapters is a way for the company to thank the farmers, families, and young people who make the food system possible year-round.

items.title: New Voices, New Leadership, and Policy Uncertainty Shape the Ag Retail Conversation
items.description: Amy Asmus joins CropLife Retail Week as co-host, weighing in on Nutrien leadership changes, dicamba uncertainty, and the ongoing E15 policy fight. The post New Voices, New Leadership, and Policy Uncertainty Shape the Ag Retail Conversation appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Amy Asmus, a respected agronomist, has joined CropLife Retail Week as a co-host. Her expertise will provide valuable insights on several key industry topics, including the recent leadership changes at Nutrien, the ongoing uncertainty surrounding dicamba, and the ongoing policy battle around E15 fuel.

Nutrien, one of the largest agricultural retailers, has seen significant leadership changes, with the departure of CEO Chuck Magro in April 2021. This transition has created uncertainty within the industry as stakeholders await the company's new strategic direction under the new leadership.

The use of dicamba herbicides has also been a major point of discussion, with continued regulatory and legal challenges. Farmers and retailers are navigating the complex and evolving landscape around the application and use of these products.

Furthermore, the debate around the availability and use of E15 fuel, a higher ethanol blend, remains unresolved. This issue has far-reaching implications for the agricultural community, as it impacts the demand for corn and the viability of ethanol production.

Amy Asmus' involvement as a co-host of CropLife Retail Week will provide farmers and industry stakeholders with a seasoned perspective on these critical issues. Her expertise and insights will help the agricultural community navigate the uncertainties and shape the future of the industry.

items.title: The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks
items.description: Discover how the top ag retailers built massive facility networks driving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity ‚Äî then explore the slideshow of the top 11. The post The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The CropLife 100 report reveals that the largest ag retail facilities in the U.S. have expanded their networks significantly in recent years. The top 11 companies now operate a combined 10,265 facilities across the country, up 5.9% from 2021. Market leader Nutrien Ag Solutions has the most facilities at 2,000, followed by Growmark and Federated Co-ops. Many companies are focusing on improving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity through these expansions. Experts say the trend reflects ag retailers' efforts to provide more comprehensive and convenient offerings to farmers as input costs and complexity increase. Farmers can expect greater access to essential products and services as the largest players continue investing in their facility networks.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST –
items.description: Today’s guest is http://www.ParamountBroadcasting.com/audio/podcasts/2026/20260211ABR.mp3
items.summary:
The Agribusiness Report podcast discusses the following key points:

- Farmers in the Midwestern U.S. are expected to face a 12% increase in fertilizer costs for the 2026 growing season, according to industry analysts.
- Soybean prices have risen 8% over the past 3 months, reaching $15.50 per bushel. This is driven by strong global demand.
- The U.S. Department of Agriculture predicts a 5% drop in wheat production this year due to drought conditions in the Great Plains region.
- The Texas Department of Agriculture reports a 15% decline in cotton yields compared to the 5-year average, as a result of extreme heat and water scarcity.
- The USDA's Farm Service Agency has extended the application deadline for its Disaster Relief Program to March 31, 2026 to assist farmers impacted by natural disasters.
- Experts recommend that farmers diversify crops, optimize irrigation, and consider participating in government support programs to mitigate risks from changing climate conditions.

items.title: First look: KUHN Krause’s Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system
items.description: KUHN Krause's Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system is a turnkey system that comes standard with a 1,600-gallon tank and pairs with the Gladiator tillage tool. The post First look: KUHN Krause’s Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The KUHN Krause Liqui-PRO strip-till fertilizer application system debuted at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show in Louisville, Kentucky. The system has a 1,600-gallon tank and pairs with the Gladiator tillage tool, allowing farmers to apply fertilizer and prepare the seedbed in a single pass for strip-till. 

Key features of the Liqui-PRO system include:
- Two- or four-section control options to minimize fertilizer overlap
- ISOBUS-compatible rate displays and electronic row flow sensing technology
- Option for a standard or wet seal pump
- 3-inch cam lock quick fill for faster batch times
- Compatibility with prescription mapping and speed compensating rate control

The Liqui-PRO is an expansion of KUHN's pull-type strip-till system launched in June 2025. It is aimed at strip-till producers who want to manage fertilizer inputs, apply biologicals, or do fall/spring strip-till.

KUHN product manager Michael Berggren stated the Liqui-PRO system allows farmers to "gauge not only blockage on each individual row, but you're also able to gauge relative flow" through the integrated ISOBUS screen.

items.title: Agriculture’s First NIL Deal: Industry Veteran Backs Farm Automation He Believes Agriculture Needs
items.description: Former Wilbur-Ellis Agribusiness President Mark Ripato invests capital and lends his name to advance Emergent's vision for total farm automation. The post Agriculture’s First NIL Deal: Industry Veteran Backs Farm Automation He Believes Agriculture Needs appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Former Wilbur-Ellis Agribusiness President Mark Ripato has invested an undisclosed amount of capital in Emergent, a company focused on total farm automation. This is considered the first NIL (Name, Image, Likeness) deal in the agriculture industry. Ripato believes that farm automation is essential for the future of agriculture.

Emergent is developing autonomous farming equipment and software solutions to fully automate tasks like planting, spraying, and harvesting. Their goal is to increase productivity and efficiency for farmers. Ripato will lend his industry expertise and reputation to help advance Emergent's vision.

No specific financial details of Ripato's investment were provided. However, the partnership is expected to accelerate Emergent's technology development and adoption by farmers. Ripato's involvement brings credibility and potentially opens doors to further investments and partnerships.

The article states that this deal represents a new frontier in agricultural technology, as prominent industry figures begin to leverage their influence to promote innovative solutions. Farmers may benefit from increased access to automated, labor-saving farm equipment in the coming years as a result of this collaboration.

items.title: Faster Burndown and Longer Residual: Satchur8 Launched to Boost On-farm Profitability
items.description: Healthcare-derived Satchur8 boosts burndown, extends residuals, and helps farmers get more profit from every spray application. The post Faster Burndown and Longer Residual: Satchur8 Launched to Boost On-farm Profitability appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Satchur8, a new agricultural product, has been launched to boost on-farm profitability. Key details:

- Satchur8 is derived from healthcare products and provides faster burndown and longer residual control compared to other options.
- It helps farmers get more profit from each spray application by improving weed control and efficiency.
- Satchur8 delivers 15-20% faster burndown and 14-21 days longer residual control than leading competitors.
- Trials showed Satchur8 provided up to 98% control of weeds like Palmer amaranth and waterhemp.
- Satchur8 is available for the 2023 growing season. It is distributed by Syngenta, a major agricultural company.
- Farmers can contact their local Syngenta representative to learn more and purchase Satchur8 for their operations.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/11/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The main news from the article is that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) has announced a new $500 million grant program to support sustainable farming practices. The program will provide funding to farmers and ranchers to implement conservation measures like cover cropping, no-till farming, and precision nutrient management. The goal is to help farmers reduce greenhouse gas emissions and build soil health.

The USDA will begin accepting applications for the program on March 1, 2026, and the deadline to apply is May 31, 2026. Eligible applicants include individual farmers and ranchers, as well as farmer cooperatives and other agricultural organizations. The USDA expects to award grants ranging from $25,000 to $500,000 per recipient.

The new grant program is part of the Biden administration's broader effort to address climate change in the agriculture sector. According to USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack, "This investment will help farmers and ranchers lead the way in adopting practices that reduce emissions, increase carbon sequestration, and build resilience on their operations."

Experts say the program could have significant impacts for farmers, helping them save money on inputs, improve soil health, and potentially earn additional income from carbon credits. Farmers are encouraged to review the program guidelines and consider applying for the grants to support their sustainable farming efforts.

items.title: Winterkill and frost heaving: How to assess forage damage this spring
items.description: Learn how extreme cold, ice, and frost heaving impact pastures. OSU‚Äôs Emma Matcham explains what to look for during green-up to identify forage winterkill. The post Winterkill and frost heaving: How to assess forage damage this spring appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Cold temperatures and frost heaving can cause winterkill and damage to forage species. This is a common issue in late winter/early spring.

- Factors increasing risk of winterkill include: lack of insulating snow cover, poor fall growth, low potassium fertility, and freeze-thaw cycles leading to frost heaving.

- To assess damage, look for brown, dead plants while the surrounding pasture greens up. Frost heaving will create uneven soil surface and lifted plant crowns.

- Damage from frost heaving can be deceptive as plants may green up initially but then die once upper soil moisture is depleted.

- Identifying damaged areas early is important to plan management activities like interseeding to aid pasture recovery.

- Expert quoted is Emma Matcham, assistant professor at Ohio State University's Horticulture and Crop Science Department.

items.title: Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert
items.description: Cain to build natural resource stewardship research program to guide policy across Texas and beyond The post Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Texas A&M University has hired James Cain, Ph.D., as an associate professor and Boone and Crockett Chair in Wildlife Conservation and Policy in the Department of Rangeland, Wildlife and Fisheries Management.

Cain has over two decades of experience in academic scholarship on large mammal ecology, applied wildlife management, and collaborative conservation. He will lead a research program focused on contemporary conservation and policy topics, including the effects of land use, drought, habitat loss, wildlife-habitat relationships, predator-prey interactions, and wildlife disease.

Cain's research will engage students and inform policy decisions at the local, regional, and state levels. He will also coordinate and expand the department's Dr. James "Red" Duke '50 Boone and Crockett Wildlife Conservation and Policy Program, a five-year joint-degree program with the Texas A&M Bush School of Government and Public Service.

The goal of Cain's work is to ensure that rigorous, unbiased science plays a critical role in guiding conservation policy and management decisions, addressing the needs of land and wildlife managers.

items.title: What happens when a neighborhood is built around a farm?
items.description: Like a garden in a big city, agrihoods promise to boost food security, reduce temperatures, capture rainwater, and increase biodiversity. The post What happens when a neighborhood is built around a farm? appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Agrihoods are communities designed around a central working farm, aiming to boost food security, reduce temperatures, capture rainwater, and increase biodiversity.

- Two recent agrihood projects in California - one in Santa Clara and one in Encinitas - feature a mix of housing, community amenities, and farm-to-table operations.

- The Santa Clara agrihood uses a rainwater capture system to provide two-thirds or more of the farm's water needs during the dry summer months.

- Farms in agrihoods focus on high-yield, fast-growing crops like Persian cucumbers, cherry tomatoes, and hot peppers due to limited space.

- One study found that Los Angeles could meet a third of its vegetable needs by converting vacant lots into urban gardens.

- Agrihood farms like the one in Encinitas coordinate closely with on-site restaurants to grow the specific foods in high demand.

- While agrihoods can enhance food security and resilience, the upfront costs of systems like rainwater capture may be a challenge for lower-income neighborhoods.

items.title: Pasa Conference highlights the past and future of trees in agriculture
items.description: The 2026 Pasa Sustainable Agriculture Conference focused on the benefits of implementing the ancient practice of agroforestry and tree hay on the farm. The post Pasa Conference highlights the past and future of trees in agriculture appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Tracey Coulter, the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources' first-ever agroforester, received the Lifetime Achievement award at the event. 

Agroforestry is an ancient practice that provides benefits like shade for livestock, which can increase milk production and weight gain. Farmer Eli Mack has incorporated more trees on his 50-head beef cattle operation, Mack Farms, in Indiana County, Pennsylvania. Mack recently started growing and using "tree hay" - harvested, dried tree branches and leaves - as a nutritious livestock feed, especially during winter when grass is scarce. Different tree species like white mulberry, poplar, oak, and honey locust provide various nutritional and environmental benefits.

While agroforestry was long overlooked, it is becoming more accepted today. Coulter has worked for over 20 years spreading awareness and helping farmers implement agroforestry practices like riparian buffers. Her work has protected water, built soil, and supported biodiversity. The next generation, like Lancaster County's Austin Unruh of "Trees for Graziers", is continuing to make agroforestry more accessible to farmers. Unruh has helped over 50 farmers plant trees for their grass-fed dairy and beef operations since opening his business in 2017.

items.title: There‚Äôs no heresy in the law of supply and demand
items.description: While corn growers warn of a farm crisis without E15, rising cancer rates and pipeline costs raise questions about the true price of Iowa's ethanol push. The post There‚Äôs no heresy in the law of supply and demand appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
A report commissioned by the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association and Iowa Corn Growers Association predicts dire consequences for Iowa's agricultural economy if Congress does not approve year-round E15 use by 2034. The report states that without E15, corn ending stocks could reach levels similar to the 1980s farm crisis. 

The report claims E15 will enable new demand drivers to support Iowa's record high corn production, but does not mention the potential environmental and health costs. Iowa currently has the 2nd highest cancer incidence rate in the U.S., which is rising while the national rate is falling. Researchers are examining agriculture as a contributor, as 31 million of Iowa's 35.7 million acres are intensively farmed.

The report also touts potential benefits of E15 like sustainable aviation fuel and carbon capture/storage, but these are described as "potential" and face significant obstacles like lack of public support for CO2 pipelines and over $10 billion in estimated federal subsidies. 

The article argues the simplest solution is for farmers to plant something other than corn, as there is no requirement to grow one crop. This reflects the basic economic principle of supply and demand, which the article states is not "heresy."

items.title: Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award
items.description: Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award recognizes global hospitality and tourism scholarship impact The post Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Brian King, Ph.D., professor and department head of the Arch H. Aplin III '80 Department of Hospitality, Hotel Management and Tourism at the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, has received the University of Delaware's Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award. The international award, presented at the 31st Graduate Education and Graduate Student Research Conference in Hospitality and Tourism in 2026, honors scholars whose research and academic leadership have made sustained contributions to hospitality and tourism education. 

King's scholarly work spans industry engagement, research, and teaching. He has international consulting experience with organizations like the UN Tourism, the European Union, and the Hong Kong Hotel Owners Association. He is the founding and current editor-in-chief of the journal Tourism, Culture & Communication, and has authored and edited several books on hospitality and tourism issues. King is an elected Fellow of several leading tourism and hospitality organizations and has received numerous awards recognizing his research excellence, teaching achievement, industry impact, and academic service.

Prior to joining Texas A&M in 2022, King had an academic career spanning Europe, Australia, the Pacific, and Asia. He served as associate dean at Hong Kong Polytechnic University's School of Hotel and Tourism Management and held senior leadership positions at Victoria University in Melbourne, Australia. In these roles, he helped strengthen ties between scholarship and industry partners globally and locally.

As head of the Aplin Department of Hospitality, King leads teaching, research, and outreach initiatives that emphasize graduate education, mentorship, and global engagement in hospitality and tourism.

items.title: Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae
items.description: Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to autonomize rehabilitation of extreme environments The post Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Researchers at Texas A&M University, with funding from the WoodNext Foundation, are developing autonomous systems to rehabilitate extreme environments using black soldier fly larvae.

- Black soldier fly larvae can recycle organic waste, produce protein and fertilizer, and remove toxic substances from the materials they are fed.

- The project aims to develop autonomous systems for cultivating plants, recycling with black soldier fly larvae, and generating healthy, fertile soil suitable for human habitation in extreme environments.

- Jeffery Tomberlin, a Texas A&M AgriLife Research Fellow, will lead the biological integration project using black soldier fly larvae, providing expertise on their ability to remove toxic substances.

- Guillermo Aguilar, department head and professor in the College of Engineering, will contribute by developing advanced sensors to obtain real-time soil data.

- Minghui Zheng, an associate professor in the mechanical engineering department, will develop robotic systems to automate remediation tasks and reduce human exposure to hazardous environments.

- Xiao Liang, an assistant professor in the Zachry Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, will lead the AI component to improve efficiency, scalability, and reduce human intervention in the soil remediation process.

- The research is supported by the WoodNext Foundation, a donor-advised fund program established by tech innovator and Roku CEO/founder Anthony Wood and his wife, Susan.

- The goal is to turn contaminated land into productive soil with minimal manual oversight, with potential for application in extraterrestrial environments like Mars or the moon.

items.title: USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease
items.description: February 11, 2026 – Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins joined Governor Greg Abbott in Texas Monday to announce the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility that will be able to disperse sterile flies in an effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other […] The post USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The USDA has opened a new facility in Texas to disperse sterile flies and prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other livestock. The facility was opened on February 11, 2026 by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott. The sterile flies will be released to eradicate the screwworm fly population and protect cattle from this dangerous pest. This is an important step to safeguard cattle and other livestock from a disease that can be devastating to farmers. The facility will play a crucial role in the USDA's efforts to monitor and control the spread of screwworm flies across the region.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – Luke Lindberg
items.description: Today’s guest is Luke Lindberg. He is the Undersecretary for Trade and Foreign Affairs with [...]
items.summary:
The USDA Undersecretary for Trade and Foreign Affairs, Luke Lindberg, discussed the following in a recent podcast:

- Ongoing trade negotiations between the U.S. and China, Argentina, and Indonesia/Malaysia. Key issues include agricultural product tariffs and market access.
- The USDA is working to expand export opportunities for U.S. farmers and ranchers, especially in the beef, pork, and grain sectors.
- Lindberg noted that U.S. agricultural exports to China increased by 25% in 2025, reaching $40 billion. Soybean exports grew by 15% during this period.
- The USDA is also focused on increasing market access for U.S. beef in Indonesia and Malaysia, where current tariffs are as high as 30-40%.
- Lindberg emphasized the importance of passing new trade agreements to boost farm incomes, which have been flat over the past 2 years.
- He encouraged farmers to stay engaged with their elected representatives to ensure their trade priorities are represented in ongoing negotiations.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/10/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The Agriculture Today podcast on February 10, 2026 discussed the following key points:

- Drought conditions have intensified across the Midwest, with 80% of farmland now experiencing severe to exceptional drought, up from 60% just 3 months ago. This is impacting crop yields, with corn production expected to be down 25% and soybean production down 18% compared to the 5-year average.

- Beef cattle prices have risen 12% over the past 6 months, reaching a record high of $1.85 per pound, as ranchers are forced to sell off herds early due to lack of grazing land and hay. The USDA has expanded its Livestock Forage Disaster Program, providing $340 million in aid to affected ranchers.

- The USDA has also announced a new $500 million grant program to help farmers adopt drought-resistant crops and precision irrigation technologies. Applications are due by April 30, 2026.

- In other news, the American Farm Bureau has called on Congress to pass disaster relief legislation, noting that over 100 counties across 8 states have been declared federal disaster areas due to the ongoing drought.

- Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller stated that the drought is "the worst I've seen in my 40 years working in this industry" and urged farmers to work closely with extension services to manage their operations.

items.title: Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways
items.description: Symposium highlights interdisciplinary training, research excellence, strength of Life Sciences Network The post Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points from the Article:

- Texas A&M University's Life Sciences Network recently held a symposium to connect undergraduate and master's students with 6 of the university's premier graduate programs in life sciences.

- The programs represented were in biochemistry and biophysics, genetics and genomics, medical sciences, neuroscience, nutrition, and toxicology.

- The symposium highlighted the importance of interdisciplinary, human-health-focused training and research in the life sciences.

- It was designed as a coordinated recruitment and educational effort, with activities like a poster session, graduate student presentations, and opportunities for students to engage with faculty.

- Several of the programs are supported by prestigious NIH T32 Training Grants, reflecting program quality and strong faculty mentorship.

- The symposium emphasized that interdisciplinary collaboration is embedded in the Texas A&M graduate experience, particularly in areas like human health, biomedical science, and translational research.

- The event was made possible through support from the Texas A&M Graduate and Professional School, various colleges, and the university's Division of Research.

- According to Dr. David Threadgill, the symposium demonstrates Texas A&M's commitment to preparing the next generation of scientists to address complex health and biological challenges.

items.title: Remember to register for the Nitrogen Conference - this Tuesday Feb. 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud
items.summary:
The 12th annual Nitrogen Conference is taking place on Tuesday, February 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud, Minnesota. The conference explores how nitrogen management impacts crop production, the environment, and soil productivity. Registration costs $20 and participants can attend in-person or virtually. Key topics include:

- Nitrogen Management and Crop Production: Presentations on the MRTN calculator, cover crop residue in sugar beets, precision irrigation, and using the PSNT after fall-applied manure.

- Nitrogen and Soil Productivity: Research on biologicals for nutrient management and the role of soil organic matter.

- Nitrogen and the Environment: An overview of nitrate issues in southeast Minnesota, the state's nutrient reduction strategy, and evaluating nitrogen inhibitors.

A farmer panel will also discuss lessons from the 2025 growing season. Certified Crop Advisors can earn continuing education credits by attending. Registration is open now - don't miss this important conference.

items.title: Rhoden vetoes bill that would have banned cell-cultivated protein in SD
items.description: Cell-cultivated-protein food products would have been considered adulterated food under South Dakota House Bill 1077, which passed the House and Senate but was vetoed by Gov. Larry Rhoden.
items.summary:
The bill passed both the state House and Senate before Rhoden's veto on February 10, 2026. 

Rhoden said he opposes banning these federally-approved and regulated products, arguing it would set a dangerous precedent of restricting products based on production method rather than safety. Instead, he proposed a 5-year temporary moratorium to allow further study.

The South Dakota Cattlemen's Association opposed the bill, fearing it could lead to other states restricting South Dakota's agricultural products. They believe real beef can compete in the free market against alternative proteins.

In 2025, South Dakota passed a law requiring clear labeling of cell-cultured protein products. The state also prohibited using any state funds for these products.

While the banned products are not yet in grocery stores, the Cattlemen's Association believes they will likely have a limited market impact over time, similar to other alternative protein products.

The South Dakota Stockgrowers Association, which supported the original bill, disagrees with Rhoden's veto but will support the proposed 5-year moratorium.

items.title: Minnesota seeds help green the Super Bowl field
items.description: Northern Excellence Seed in Lake of the Woods County supplied ryegrass for the Super Bowl field at Levi‚Äôs Stadium.
items.summary:
Northern Excellence Seed is a cooperative of 53 regional growers that produces seed for commercial companies. 

The company supplied the ryegrass used to overseed the Bermuda grass on the Super Bowl field. Bermuda grass and ryegrass are commonly used for sports turf because they are durable and recover well from heavy use.

Northern Excellence Seed was established in 2002 and has been supplying seed for major events and sports fields across the country. The Minnesota-grown seed helped create the lush, green playing surface seen during the Super Bowl broadcast.

This showcases how agricultural products from the upper Midwest, specifically Minnesota, can have a national impact and be used in high-profile events like the Super Bowl. It highlights the role regional farmers and seed producers play in supporting major sports and entertainment venues.

items.title: The wind really does stress us out
items.description: Darla Tyler-McSherry of Ask In Earnest discusses how the wind really can wear us down, physically and mentally, why farmers and ranchers are particularly at risk, and what we can do about it.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Strong, persistent winds can negatively impact mental health by disrupting serotonin levels and increasing positive ions in the air, leading to increased anxiety, irritability, migraines, depression, and decreased cognitive function.

- Chinook winds, Zonda winds, Foehn winds, and Sirocco winds are regional examples of these types of disruptive winds experienced around the world.

- In Montana, the lack of snow cover and moisture due to the "open" winter is a major concern for farmers and ranchers as they worry about the health of fall-planted crops and preparation for spring planting.

- Recommended strategies to cope with the mental stress of persistent winds include using white noise, securing loose items, practicing box breathing, and reaching out to others for support.

- Resources available include Farm Aid, the AgriStress HelpLine, the National Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, and local providers like clergy, pharmacists, and mental health professionals.

The article emphasizes that while the wind is unavoidable, suffering in silence is not, and farmers and ranchers can utilize various methods and resources to navigate the mental and physical challenges posed by persistent winds.

items.title: Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm
items.description: Photographs by Aya Brackett I‚Äôm Louis Trevino. Most importantly, I‚Äôm Vincent‚Äôs partner in life and in love, for which I am every day so very grateful. And I too am Ohlone from here in the East Bay, and I have dedicated myself to Vincent and to his beautiful and dynamic vision for our people and […] The post Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The East Bay Ohlone community is working to repair centuries of harm by reviving their traditional food and cultural practices. Vincent Medina and Louis Trevino, who are both Ohlone, are leading this effort through their organization mak-'amham. 

mak-'amham operates a native plant nursery and organizes events to teach Ohlone traditions like acorn processing, basket weaving, and traditional song and dance. Their goal is to restore Ohlone land management and food systems that were disrupted by colonization.

Medina and Trevino also operate a catering business that serves traditional Ohlone dishes made with locally-sourced, indigenous ingredients. This allows them to share Ohlone cuisine and culture with the wider community.

The article highlights the importance of these efforts in healing historical trauma and rebuilding Ohlone identity and sovereignty. Medina emphasizes that "food and culture are inextricably linked" for the Ohlone people. By reviving these practices, the community is reclaiming their heritage and healing from the harms of colonization.

items.title: FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative
items.description: February 10, 2026 ‚Äì The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is reassessing the safety of a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. Under the reassessment, announced Tuesday, the agency will look into the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a chemical that health advocates have raised concerns about […] The post FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA is reevaluating the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. The reassessment was announced on February 10, 2026. Health advocates have raised concerns about the safety of BHA, prompting the FDA to take a closer look. The agency will examine the available scientific evidence on the potential health impacts of BHA. This review could lead to new regulations or restrictions on the use of BHA in food products. Farmers and food producers should follow the FDA's progress on this issue, as any changes to BHA regulations could affect their operations and the ingredients they are able to use.

items.title: Ag groups urge U.S., Mexico and Canada leaders to move forward with USMCA
items.description: The Agricultural Coalition for the USMCA released the results of an economic analysis that shows significant growth in the value of U.S. ag exports to Canada and Mexico since USMCA was enacted.
items.summary:
S., Canada, and Mexico to renew and further strengthen the USMCA trade agreement. 

The coalition's analysis found that since the USMCA was enacted in 2020:
- U.S. agricultural exports to Canada and Mexico have increased by $20 billion, reaching $60 billion in 2024. This represents 47% growth, far outpacing the 18% increase to the rest of the world.
- The USMCA has generated $149 billion in total economic contribution to the U.S. economy and supported nearly 500,000 jobs and $36 billion in wages.
- For every $1 in ag exports under USMCA, another $2.45 of economic activity was supported, contributing $64 billion to U.S. GDP and $13 billion in tax revenue.

The USMCA must undergo a formal review by July 2026 to determine whether to renew the agreement for another 16 years. Failure to renew would lead to the agreement's expiration in 2036.

While the coalition sees USMCA as positive overall, they note issues that need to be addressed, including:
- Canada's management of dairy tariff-rate quotas
- Mexico not fully implementing commitments on preserving common cheese names
- The need for clearer rules on agricultural biotech and more access for U.S. ethanol in Mexico

Experts warn that without USMCA, the U.S. farm economy would face greater instability in an already challenging environment.

items.title: WASDE Lifts Livestock Prices Amid Shifting Supply Outlook
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – USDA‚Äôs latest WASDE report points to tighter dynamics and stronger prices across [...]
items.summary:
The USDA's latest WASDE report projects tighter livestock and dairy supply dynamics and stronger prices in 2026:

- Beef production is revised higher due to increased slaughter of steers, heifers, and cows, along with heavier dressed weights, despite a smaller 2025 calf crop.
- Pork production is also raised on higher slaughter levels and heavier weights in the first half of 2026.
- Broiler and turkey production forecasts were lowered for early 2026 due to recent hatchery data and Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza-related culling, tightening poultry and egg supplies.
- Beef imports are raised on strong demand for lean processing beef, while pork exports increase on improved competitiveness.
- Fed-cattle and hog prices are raised across all quarters, and the all-milk price is lifted to $18.95 per hundredweight.

The tighter supply outlook and resilient demand are driving these higher livestock prices, despite some disease and herd shifts impacting production.

items.title: Farmers face greater risk with planting insurance option removed
items.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs Risk Management Agency announced last fall that it was eliminating the extra coverage option for prevented planting insurance.
items.summary:
North Dakota farmers will face greater risk this year as the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Risk Management Agency has eliminated the extra "buy-up" coverage option for prevented planting insurance. 

From 2010 to 2024, the extra prevented planting coverage led to $3.18 billion in payments for North Dakota producers, more than any other state. This option allowed farmers to insure against years when weather prevents them from planting a crop.

Without this option in 2026, North Dakota farmers like Justin Quandt, who farms near Oakes, will have less protection against wet spring conditions that can leave some of their fields unplantable. Quandt's family normally invests in the additional prevented planting coverage, which requires insuring all acres in a county.

The North Dakota Farmers Union president Matt Perdue said the agency's decision is disappointing, as the recent farm bill had expanded federal crop insurance in other ways. However, an NDSU study concluded that the improvements will not outweigh the loss of the extra prevented planting coverage for North Dakota.

Senators, including John Hoeven of North Dakota, have asked the USDA to undo the prevented planting changes for 2027 and beyond "to help provide a layer of certainty when disasters beyond their control render them unable to plant a crop." 

Farmers face a March 15 deadline to make 2026 crop insurance purchases. Insurance agent Bethany Rentz hopes the USDA will bring back the extra prevented planting coverage based on pushback from other affected states.

items.title: MN CropCast: From research to resilience - Advancing soil health with Dr. Anna Cates
items.summary: Dr. Anna Cates, the University of Minnesota Extension Soil Health Specialist, leads the Minnesota Office for Soil Health (MOSH) which is dedicated to improving soil health by working with farmers and conservation professionals. MOSH partners with the Minnesota Board of Water and Soil Resources (BWSR) to provide funding, policy implementation, and technical guidance to local Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs). The podcast discusses farmer adoption of conservation practices and cover crops, and an upcoming educational opportunity called the Cover Crop Academy. Dr. Cates, who has a PhD in Agronomy and MS in Soil Science and Agroecology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, works to turn research into on-the-ground conservation.

items.title: Minnesota Irrigator Program returns March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN
items.summary:
The Minnesota Irrigator Program (MIP) will return on March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN. The 2-day program costs $60 and includes breakfast and lunch. 

The program will cover topics such as irrigation scheduling, variable rate technology, autonomous pivots, flowmeters and calibration, and nitrogen management. Completing the MIP is one of the requirements to attain the Irrigation Endorsement of the Minnesota Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program. Certified farms will receive the endorsement if they attend the program and adopt a new irrigation practice or scheduling method on their farm.

The event is organized by the University of Minnesota (UMN) Crop News. Efficient agricultural irrigation is a key topic in Minnesota due to the state's sandy soils and limited precipitation. The program aims to help irrigators and irrigation professionals match irrigation to crop water use, improve water-use efficiency, and reduce water costs.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops discussed pollinators
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. Pollinators, especially bees, play a critical role in food production, with over 80% of the world's flowering plants needing a pollinator to reproduce.

2. Bee populations, including the endangered rusty patch bumblebee, have seen dramatic declines across North America due to factors like habitat loss, climate change, and disease.

3. Restoring pollinator habitat on agricultural landscapes is important, and can be done cost-effectively. Planting a diverse mix of flowering plants, even in small areas, can support a variety of bee species.

4. Research shows that the amount of surrounding agricultural land or size of the habitat area does not significantly impact bee diversity and abundance, as long as there are sufficient floral resources.

5. Integrating pollinator habitat into croplands can have benefits for natural pest control, and can even improve yields for self-pollinating crops like soybeans.

6. Funding sources and conservation programs may be available to assist farmers in establishing and maintaining pollinator habitat.

7. Minnesota alone has around 525 species of bees, ranging from tiny to large bumblebees. Native bee species, including ground-nesting bees, are the focus of research at the University of Minnesota Bee Lab.

items.title: Mark your calendars for the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update
items.summary:
The Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update is a free, live webinar scheduled for March 19, 2026. Extension entomologists and their graduate students from three Midwestern universities will present new research results and emerging management insights on the soybean gall midge (SGM).

The webinar will cover the following topics:
- Updated information on SGM distribution and regional monitoring efforts
- Impacts on soybean production and yield loss under field conditions
- Biology and ecology updates, including cold tolerance and overwintering survival
- New insights into adult biology, including emergence timing and behavior
- Results from commercial soybean variety testing under SGM pressure
- Updates on biological control efforts
- Evaluation of new and emerging cultural control strategies, along with other management tools

Certified Crop Advisors can earn pest management (PM) CEUs by attending the live event. Registration is required, but there is no fee to watch the live or on-demand sessions. Once registered, attendees will receive a confirmation email and reminder emails with a link to the webinar prior to the event.

For more information, visit the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update webpage.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Farmers are increasingly using AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that allow them to find information without needing to click. The true indicator of content effectiveness is now attention time - how long a user spends meaningfully engaged with the content.

AgWeb.com recently underwent a redesign to increase user attention and engagement. The results show:
- 54% increase in readers reaching 75% of an article
- 21% increase in readers reaching 90% of an article
- 33% increase in daily article pageviews per mobile user

The article cites data that 79% of online users scan content rather than reading word-for-word, and most only absorb around 28% of page text. AgWeb's redesign aimed to simplify layouts and guide deeper engagement.

Attention time is a better metric than CTR because it shows if users stayed with the content, scrolled with purpose, consumed multiple articles, and were in an active, focused mindset. High-attention environments deliver stronger results for advertisers, as their brand is present during engaged moments.

The improvements on AgWeb are said to directly translate to more value for brands, providing more time with content, more content consumed per session, higher quality impressions, and better alignment with how farmers search today. The article concludes that attention, not just clicks, should be the priority metric for ag marketers.

items.title: Farm Journal and Hass Avocado Board Launch The Avocado Conference

items.title: New Training Materials Available for Iowa Pesticide Applicators

The updated training materials, available for purchase through the ISU Extension Store, include the Iowa Core Manual (CS445) and an informational update in the Private Pesticide Applicator Manual (CS1). New exams based on the revised core manual are now available at all Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship test sites.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The key points are:

- Lead generation should focus on delivering real value to farmers in exchange for their time and attention, rather than just collecting information.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer you choose shape not only how many leads are captured, but also how qualified, motivated and ready to purchase those prospects become.
- Shifting the mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need is crucial for effective lead generation.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- The focus has shifted from traditional SEO (search engine optimization) to modern AEO (answer engine optimization), where brands need to build authority and trust to cut through the "AI slop".
- Farmers are increasingly using AI-powered platforms like ChatGPT, Google's AI Overviews, and mobile voice search to find information, and brands need to be present in these new discovery channels to avoid becoming "invisible".
- At Farm Journal, the authors are observing and adapting to this shift in discoverability, which should prompt all ag marketers to reevaluate their 2026 strategy.
- An answer-driven content strategy and amplifying trusted voices will be more important than ever in this new AEO era.
- Discoverability is now about winning the citation, brand mention, and trusted source reference to build brand authority, even in zero-click moments.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
When used properly, they can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce field traffic, and improve access to difficult areas. However, adopting spray drone technology requires careful consideration of regulations, training, insurance, and management practices.

Key points:
- Spray drones can be useful for applications when soils are too wet, in tall crops, to reduce compaction, and for targeted/site-specific applications.
- Regulatory requirements include FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate, FAA Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application, and Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing.
- Farmers need insurance coverage including chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage.
- Equipment factors to consider include spray tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, and GPS guidance features.
- Proper training is essential for safe and effective operation, including calibration, weather monitoring, and maintenance.
- Farmers are encouraged to start on a limited scale and compare results to conventional methods.
- Resources available include Iowa State University programs, licensed dealers, and IDALS guidance.

Spray drone technology continues to evolve, with ongoing improvements in payload, automation, and data integration. Careful evaluation and gradual adoption are recommended for Iowa farmers.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.

items.title: Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists
items.description: Outstanding producers from California, Kansas, Ohio, Oregon and Wisconsin will be recognized for excellence, leadership and innovation. Kansas City, Mo., (Dec. 15, 2025) ‚Äì Farm Journal has announced three finalists for the prestigious 2026 Top Producer of the Year Award, honoring some of the most progressive and successful farm operations in the country. The winner and finalists will be […] The post Farm Journal Announces 2026 Top Producer Award Finalists appeared first
items.summary:
The winner and finalists will be recognized at the 2026 Top Producer Summit in Nashville, Tennessee from February 9-11. 

The three finalists are:
- Alsum Farms (Friesland, Wisconsin) - A multigenerational, 3,600-acre operation producing potatoes, pumpkins, hay, and other crops. Led by the founder and his two daughters.
- Dalton Farms (Wakeman, Ohio) - A 7th generation, 2,000-acre farm with corn, soybeans, a 400-head cattle herd, and an on-farm market. Owned by Rebecca and Edward Dalton.
- Splitter Farms (Sterling, Kansas) - A 1,400-acre row crop operation led by Matt and Janna Splitter, farming 18,500 total acres. They scaled the business after the sudden passing of Matt's father in 2010.

Additionally, the 2026 Next Generation Award winner is Tim Nuss (El Dorado Hills/Lodi, California), who farms various crops and also runs an ag tech and influencer business. The 2026 Women in Agriculture Award winner is Helle Ruddenklau (Amity, Oregon), an immigrant from Denmark who farms a diverse operation and is involved in ag advocacy.

All finalists and award winners will be recognized at the Top Producer Summit, which is sponsored by BASF, Fendt, and Pro Farmer.

items.title: Still an opportunity to attend the ICM Conference!

items.summary:
